title: After destruction of Typhoon Hagibis, Japan end uncertain weekend with a pulsating win over Scotland
text:
For a short time, at the end of a long weekend, Japan fell silent.

No more thudding rain, no more howling wind, no more groaning buildings, no more wailing sirens.

The death and destruction caused by Typhoon Hagibis will not be undone in a few quiet moments. But on Sunday it was time to stop and remember.

Japan's fans were deafening as they saw their team qualify for the World Cup quarter-finals

Spectators undertook a minute's silence for the victims of Typhoon Hagibis prior to the game

Then came the noise - deafening and unrelenting in the aftermath of tragedy.

When Japan awoke on Sunday, it was unclear whether this game would even take place. Come kick-off, nearly 70,000 supporters were in for the ride.

The home side's pulsating victory was the perfect climax to all the uncertainty.

'Many people in Japan received the hazard (warnings during the typhoon) but they can see this game and the players can encourage the people,' says fan Wataru Ota.

'I hope every Japanese person sees this game and is united and motivated.'

In contrast, this proved a dark night for Scotland. For fans such as John Reilly, however, even defeat is better than another day without rugby.

Victory for Japan sees them get past the group stage for the first time in their history

Fans dressed in all sorts of colourful costumes to get into the spirit of the game in Yokohama

He came here for England's cancelled clash with France and Saturday night's epic.

'I had kittens that it wasn't going to take place,' he says. 'The Japanese have been absolutely fantastic... I'm so glad they're playing tonight.

'I'd rather we lost and get beaten in a match than (go out) on bonus points.'

Away from the bright lights, stadium staff worked doggedly to make this night so special.

That there were so few scars of the typhoon owes much to this country's rapidly changing weather - and the spirit of its people.

A Tokyo fanzone saw scores of fans gather to watch the exciting match against Scotland

Japan fans stayed after the game in Yokohama to pay tribute to their victorious players

In the early hours one local was seen clearing debris and staff continued the cleaning operation before a World Rugby even announced the game was on.

By late afternoon the area surrounding the ground was spotless.

There were also warnings that merchandise, food and drink stalls would be hampered by the storm but everyone made do. Fans were allowed to bring their own soft drinks. Many came with food, too.

Beers were available from inside a makeshift tarpaulin tent, while the youngsters carrying mobile Heineken taps did their best to raise spirits. The Japan players did the rest.
description: DANIEL MATTHEWS IN YOKOHAMA: Japan reached the quarter finals of the Rugby World Cup with victory over Scotland. It comes after the death and destruction of Typhoon Hagibis.
